text:
SPEAKER: Well, I want to
introduce Vern Norviel, who is an Emeritus partner at
Wilson, Sonsini, Goodrich

& Rosati, where he was a senior
practitioner in the firm's patents and innovations
counseling practice.

So he has three
decades of experience formulating successful
strategies for life science companies and helping
them develop IP programs.

That's what we hope to learn
a little bit more about and learn from that experience. He's represented a wide
variety of companies,

as well as venture capital firms
in areas such as therapeutics, diagnostics, nanotechnology,
genomics, proteomics,

personalized medicine. And in fact, I think
one interesting fact is that Vern, you've had
your entire genome sequenced

and it's available
in a public database. Apparently, you're the
first attorney to do that.

I'm not sure if there are
a lot who followed suit. Be interested to learn if that's
become a practice among life

sciences attorneys. Before joining Wilson
and Sonsini in 2003,

Vern was the general counsel
and corporate secretary of religion sciences. And before that he was
senior vice-president

and general counsel and an
early employee of Affymetrix, which was a really important
biotechnology company

that pioneered and developed
DNA chip technology. He also served as a partner
at Townsend and Townsend

and Crew in Palo Alto. And during that long career,
Vern also authored or prosecuted

more than 20 patents that
have been litigated in the US and around the world. He's overseen intellectual
property lawsuits

throughout the world as well. So building on all
that experience, Vern is also a lecturer
here at Stanford University

at the School of Medicine. He teaches a class that will
be happening this spring in biotechnology law.

We'll be talking again. That's what the topic of
today's conversation is. And we'll learn a little bit
about it at a high level.

If you are interested,
again, that's a course that you
can take with Vern, even if you're not a
matriculated Stanford student.

Go ahead and click on that link,
you can learn about it more. And we'll go into more detail
at the end of this session.

So Vern, thank you so
much for joining us today. I'm really excited to
have this conversation.

And let's just kick it off
at the very highest level. The kind of 30,000 feet is,
what is biotechnology law?

And why is it especially
critical for life sciences innovation? I'll hand it off to you.

VERN NORVIEL: So I guess I
can define it any way I want, since I think I
started the term.

First of all, I think if
you're a lawyer, by the way, or if you're wanting to be
a lawyer, this is the best--

I think I have the
best job in the world because I get to spend
my days with people that are just wicked smart.

And they're doing
things that are going to save lives, literally. And then they pay you for it.

It's like a dream come true. It really is a dream job that
I've had for a long time.

Actually, my bio is a
little outdated there. It's now four decades,
unfortunately or fortunately,

that I've been doing this. Literally, when I
started law school, I don't think the word
biotechnology existed.

There was no such industry. There was no Genentech. There was no nothing. So I've, in a sense, been doing
this before the industry even

existed. So it's been a while. And I've seen pretty
much the whole movie.

But what is biotechnology law? So it's a way for me to think
about it more than anything.

But being a lawyer
in the life science industry for all this time,
it has become obvious to me

that the sea level and
management teams and boards

of a life science
company end up being some of the best lawyers I know.

This is born of necessity. It is much different than
other areas like software

and so forth, semiconductors,
where the legal parts actually really matter.

They're strategic issues. They're not tactical issues. So it was my observation
that in training

the future CEOs and C-level
executives of life science companies, it would
be a good thing

to have them up to
speed so they weren't learning on the job about all
the legal issues that come up.

So that's what it is.  SPEAKER: Yeah, that's
a great high level.

And what I'd love to dig in
more on is what you just-- one entry point is
you mentioned it's

different from the
considerations of, say, a software or semiconductor
firm, which are obviously a lot of what we see
here in the Bay Area,

or did see a lot
of in the Bay Area. And that when you're
thinking about it

in a life sciences firm
that they're strategic, not tactical decisions, could
you dig in a little bit-- provide a little bit
more detail, what

are some of those differences? I mean, what makes
it so different to be a CEO in a
life sciences firm?

Why is law so front and center
for those firms versus something like a semiconductor, or a
chip maker, or a chip designer?

VERN NORVIEL: So it is
dramatically different. And I'll go through
some of the areas of law and give as examples.

Again, oddly, since I started
before biotech was a word, I actually did work
on semiconductors.

I actually have an engineering
degree, shockingly. I got my engineering degree
before dirt was invented.

So it wasn't terribly relevant. But I am familiar with that. I worked on some very wonderful
companies like Altera and so
forth in the Bay Area long ago. But it is very different. And why is it different?

So let's just take patents as
one of the leading examples. In a semiconductor company,
or in a software company,

or dot com company,
that sort of thing,

it is not uncommon, for example,
for a semiconductor chip to need hundreds or
thousands of patents

from all kinds of players
to be able to make them. And so licensing is an
everyday thing there.

There are almost
routines for how you go about licensing between
big companies in that industry.

Almost nobody
views their patents as a strategic
asset, where they are

people starting from
that side definitely think that their
patents are going

to be used to shut people
down who get close to them. Now, why is there that
dramatic difference?

Well, I use Facebook
as an example. And my numbers may
be off a little bit, but they're not off
in any meaningful way.

But it took Facebook $200
million to become profitable.

I think they raised a little
more money after that, but that's what it took
for them to be profitable.

If you're starting
a drug program to starting to develop a
drug, for some reason, Tufts

University, I don't know how
they got this role in the world, but every year they come up with
the latest estimate for what

it takes to develop a drug. And their latest estimates are
in the range of $2 billion.

So that obviously has a lot
more zeros than Facebook. Now, why is that important?

Well, if you're going
to invest $2 billion in something, if you're
a venture fund, let's

say, starting that out,
or a big biotech that's buying a small company,
or starting a drug

program themselves,
you have to be assured that you're
going to have huge margins, for at
least a little while,

on that, hopefully,
huge product. These products do tend to be
multi-billion dollar products.

And they do tend to have
90% plus gross margins. None of that's true with
the software companies

or the semiconductor companies. Yeah, they'll eventually
get to those kinds of sales, but it takes far less
money to get there.

The investment is far less. So they can afford to
have people getting up a little closer to them
and maybe chewing away

at their margins a bit. It's completely unacceptable
in the drug business. If you don't have
a story for why

you won't even raise a series
A. So it's a brick wall. And to some extent,
it doesn't matter

whether what I say
is real or not, it is believed to be
real amongst everyone

in the industry. So regardless of whether
it's right or wrong, it's true because people
believe it to be true.

So patents are not
everything, but they are a link in a chain
that if it's not there,

you're not going
to develop a drug. Similarly, if you take
regulatory law, which is usually

a relatively small part of
any tech kind of company,

regulatory law is also
another link in the chain. If you don't have an FDA
strategy for how you're

going to get your trials done
at a rational cost, how you're going to get them done
in a rational speed,

so you're not starting to sell
the drug 20 years from now. And how your patent--
believe it or not,

there are interlinks between
FDA law and patent law. And if you don't have those
links clearly outlined,

you will, again, not get funded. So it's a brick wall. You've got to know
your regulatory law.

And interestingly, even in
more mundane, seemingly, things like contracts,
there's a kind of thing

that happens in life science
called strategic partnering, where small companies will
partner with big companies

most often or frequently. And they will do
things like develop

a drug in a particular area,
or develop a particular drug together. These are obviously
very expensive.

And the big companies like
sharing some of the risk with a small company
and vice-versa.

That kind of collaboration
doesn't really exist outside of life science.

But yet, there are entire groups
at firms like Wilson, Sonsini,

or Cooley, or Latham
that don't do anything except that it is what they do.

And they do it very well. And it's very complicated. These contracts are
sometimes many inches thick,
sometimes a foot or two thick. And it's super complicated.

So the reason I bring all
this up is if this is all-- and that's also a link in the
chain that if you screw that up,

you're done. So you have all
these legal links in the chain of building
a valuable life science

company that honestly just don't
really exist in other companies.

And as a result, what you see
is the sea level management

of a life science
company, all of them will be top of the legal issues.

They will know their
contracts with a capital K. They will know their
patents with a capital

K. They will know the regulatory
strategy with a capital K. So it's just different.

I don't think the
successful CEOs of many of the tech
companies really dig

in that much to
any of those areas. SPEAKER: That's really
a great overview.

So just kind of summarizing,
what I'm hearing is, one, that the longer
timeline to commercialization, or the higher levels
of capital needed

to bring a drug company
or a drug to profitability is one reason you need to have
a very set strategy around IP.

And then the other
two additional links in the chain, as
you call them, where a regulatory strategy, because
especially pharmaceuticals

and medicine are going
to be highly regulated, is having that
link in the chain. And then finally, because
of these, the unique way

biotechnology firms
often collaborate, or partner with other
biotechnology firms

is that, that contract piece
is also really essential, those three links in the chain. And so it's important if
you're a CEO, or thinking

of being a CEO, or trying to
get into senior management of any kind of these
life science companies,

to really be aware
of those legal issues and how they potentially
dictate the path

that your company can follow. What I'd love to do then
maybe is dig a little bit more

into this idea of
developing an IP strategy. If I am recalling
correctly, that's something

that you worked on extensively. And so I'd love to-- let's say there's someone
on the call right now

who's thinking about
that IP strategy, can you walk through some of
the high level consideration?

So things that I know-- the
scope and breadth of patents analysis around the
freedom to operate

and what that means, the
cost of IP ownership, and let's start with those
and any others that you think

are worthwhile. And just walking through
those, if I'm a CEO, or I'm someone thinking of a
life sciences company, what

goes into that IP strategy? VERN NORVIEL: Great question. So this is one of those very
important links in the chain.

And it's a term you don't really
hear, again, outside of the life science industry. Again, I worked for
semiconductor companies

long ago. And if you said you
had an IP strategy, it wouldn't really mean much
to anybody in those industries.

What that would mean
to them probably is we're going to try to
file three patents a month. And we don't really care what
they are, or what they cover,

or anything like that. But we're just going to try to
keep the cost down and get three patents filed every month.

That might be the deepest
thinking that goes into it. And conversely, on
the side of freedom

to operate, meaning
freedom to operate, meaning does anyone else
have a patent that covers me?

I mean, there are
very large companies that are in the Bay Area that
their general counsel say,

we don't want engineers
or scientists even looking at patents because we don't
want to know about them.

We specifically want our
heads buried in the sand. Because once we know about them,
we might have to deal with them.

Utterly the opposite
in my sense. So in life science, you
will always hear these days,

any venture fund that is
invested in life science will view the IP
strategy as being

pivotal for their
investment thesis. Now, it will mean different
things to different companies.

If you just invented
CRISPR, you might want to dominate the
entire world of CRISPR

and come up with a patent
strategy, where you're going to have broad patents
that cover the whole thing,

and medium patents that cover
maybe specific disease areas, and then narrow
patents that cover

the exact drugs that you're
going to move forward. Conversely, if you're a
small molecule drug company,

you want to just carpet bomb
that exact small molecule. So there's always a
strategy around it.

Timing is also important. When you get into those
partnering discussions

that I mentioned with,
say, a big pharma, it is one thing to walk
into those partnering

meetings with patent
applications and say, we think we'll get
patents someday.

Big companies like Roche
will, in an attempt, frankly, to negotiate
with you, will frequently

find a million reasons why
you'll never get a patent, and use it to bring the
price down for partnering.

But if you bring an issue
patent into the room, then it changes
the conversation.

And I've had M&A
discussions going on when we got patents
allowed and it completely turned the thing upside down.
So timing matters. What you're filing matters.

And every I has to be dotted. And every T has to be crossed. Because for every financing and
every partnering discussion,

there will be massive
diligence done. Stepping back one
step, I would say

that some of the big
pharma's do deeper diligence than you get in a
lawsuit someday when

you sue to enforce the patents. These people are super
insightful, super smart lawyers.

And they'll turn up
everything, even more sometimes than the
law the lawsuits will.

So every I has to be dotted. Every T has to be crossed. And it's a lot better
to have issue patterns

than pending applications. And again, you need to
have a Venn diagram showing what the big level strategy is.

Now, freedom to operate is
the flip side of all that. And as opposed to getting
patents to stop people,

it's the flip side,
which means you need to know, in life
science companies,

that there is no one
that can stop you. And by nobody, I mean nobody. It's a very
unforgiving question.

You have to find everything that
is, or even could be a problem.

Because if you've
developed a drug and you're halfway through
the development process

and you've spent $1
billion and you find out someone else has a patent
that covers what you're doing,

somebody is going to be
all kinds of unhappy. So in life science, you have to
have zero risk, or very, very

low risk of any freedom
to operate problems from a third-party. So part of the strategy is
often to do those freedom

to operate studies
very early on. And then if you find a
problem, very frequently,

the VCs and management will
want you to just go buy it. If there's a patent
out there that's

owned by Harvard, or some
small company, or whatever, before they get a bunch
of money invested,

they want you to just go nail
that patent if it's a problem and make it an asset
rather than a liability.

So that is often
part of the strategy, especially early
on is to go buy, I refer to these as loose bricks
because they're laying around

out there, and someday, somebody
might pick it up and throw it at you. So you need to go out and
pick up all the loose bricks

at some point in the
development of the company, or they will get picked up and
thrown back at you if you have

a multi-billion dollar drug. So that's another part of
the life science strategy-- again, freedom to operate.

I know with some big
companies here in the Bay Area that you can immediately name
off the top of your head, there is an absolute
aversion to knowing

about any potential
infringement problem. So it's exactly
flipped on its head. But no venture fund
is going to put money

in if there's a freedom
to operate risk. SPEAKER: Interesting! And then to your point
of buying that patent--

or I guess you can
also license it. So that's itself a whole other--

that maybe comes back
into those contracts, those foot thick contracts
that you were saying. And I know for a
lot of our audience

who will be coming
from a university and are themselves developing
within the auspices of the university, there's
those licensing considerations

as well if they're taking their
discoveries onto a company. VERN NORVIEL: Yeah,
I occasionally

run into naive CEOs or
whatever, that they will find a patent from some university.

Frequently, it's
from university. Because let's be real,
notwithstanding what you read in the newspapers
in the last few months,

pretty much everything is
invented at universities and health care at some point. If you find one of those, a
naive CEO, their knee jerk

reaction will be, well, let's
get prepared to fight it. And that's only the naive
CEOs that want to do that.

The ones that have got
scars on their back will immediately say what I
say, which is let's go get it,

let's buy it. And I always come
back and say, look,

let's say that you're
a Stanford startup and you have to license a
Harvard patent, so be it.

The way I think of it is
Harvard did something cool. If the drug is
successful, they deserve

a little bit of money to pump
up the endowment or whatever. What the heck? And so admirable
university, let's

not try to get ready
to fight with them. Let's try to get ready
to be their friends. So only the naive
management teams

will try to first
prepare to fight. SPEAKER: What does in terms
of-- we got a question coming

from the audience, just
if you are doing research and you come up with
something novel that

deserves a patent, what is it? Just, what does that look like? Just even getting your
first patent or developing,

what is the cost of that? I mean, because I imagine
research has to go into that. Maybe not the
freedom to operate,

but just understanding
what the landscape is, what similar patents
out there might be. What's the timeline
and cost of that?

VERN NORVIEL: Well, before
you even go to the VCs, you have to have filed your
patents because you can't be talking about it with the VCs
until you're filed your patents.

Because I don't think anyone
ever does this purposefully, but sometimes, the venture
funds can be a little bit leaky.

So you want your patent filed
before you talk to them. So you have to do that now.

The problem is it costs
money, as you just indicated.

This is a sport of kings. This is very expensive. This is not grandpa's garage,
where he discovered a new doodad

to file a patent on. So typically in life science,
the significant firms will

charge between
$15,000 and $30,000, depending on the subject matter,
to get a decent patent filed

initially. But that's just the
beginning of the money. At 12 months, you'll have
to file what's called a PCT,

which is another
5,000 or 10,000. And then the real money
starts flowing at 30 months because you have to file
in China, Japan, Europe.

You have to file in
individual countries. And typically for a drug kind
of portfolio, a thin portfolio,

might be just Europe,
Japan, China, maybe, that's on the order
of 100,000, 150,000.

If you go for the Glaxo, big
pharma kind of footprint, it's going to be hundreds
of thousands of dollars

just to file. Now, of course, every
one of those filings, the patent officers always
come back every time

and say, oh, I think
this is obvious. And there are reasons they do
that, that are justifiable.

Even if they think
it isn't obvious, they will say it's obvious. And then you'll have to make
your case for why you think

you're entitled to the patent. Frequently, that goes
for several rounds. And you're paying lawyers all
along the way, a lot of money.

And you think that US
lawyers are expensive, just wait till you talk
to a European lawyer, then you'll learn what
expensive really is.

So the way I put it, when
we decide to file a patent, and when I was a GC, is to
make it a lot more real,

and it actually has scaled
pretty well over the years, is that every time we decide
to file a patent here,

it's pretty much the equivalent
of hiring one or two FTEs, one or two scientists.

So that makes it a lot
more real and makes people think a lot about whether
we're going to file that patent or not.

Do you want two
scientists, or do you want one patent application? It is very expensive.

It is also very necessary. So the important ones
have to be filed. And then, of course, if you
actually ever get to litigation,

God forbid, all of
that money is trivial compared to what the
litigators will spend.

It will be-- I think the ABA said the average
lawsuit is now $10 million

or something. So it's a serious
sport of kings. It's not for
dabbling or dabblers.

And you got to get the money. The VCs will be glad to pay
it, as long as it's worth it.

SPEAKER: Interesting. And just backing up on one
thing that you mentioned is when you're thinking
of your IP strategy, you're obviously
not just thinking,

if you're a US-based
firm, the US. You've got to be
thinking globally. And so you're thinking
that freedom to operate

is not just your freedom
to operate within the US but in Europe, in Asia,
in different countries,

and specific countries. So you're thinking of what
are the biggest markets and then you're targeting them
with your patent applications.

VERN NORVIEL: So those
C level executives, not only do they have
to be US law experts, but they actually
need to know some

of the big differences between
Europe and the United States. So it's pretty much
the United States versus the rest of the world.

And there are non-trivial
differences that really matter. So take EPO as an
example, erythropoietin,

a huge drug for Amgen,
because of various things, their European
patent got blown up.

And I believe it was
Roche came on the market really early in Europe and that
was a huge value loss for Amgen.

So you need to know not
only the United States, but you need to know Europe. And there are differences.

So and it's really
unfortunately, not the kind of thing where a
CEO can always have their lawyer
at their side. They need to know it themselves.

SPEAKER: And this
is maybe getting a little bit ahead of us. But I'd be curious if
you have any thoughts on how that kind of research--

I mean, again, you
have artificial-- I mean, how do you do
that kind of research? I mean, is there a
database for patents?

I mean, how do you
search through patents? Is that something that you're
seeing firm specializing-- AI firm, especially,
software firms

and doing that kind of research? Because I imagine it's right now
very labor and time intensive.

And it relies on people who
have deep knowledge of the area. So how are those
searches even conducted?

And are you seeing changes
in the way they've been done, especially in recent years? VERN NORVIEL: Well, AI
might change in the future.

It hasn't changed so far because
the fundamental problem is that this is a fault
intolerant system.

If you have a freedom to
operate problem out there, you must find it. And even if it's not an
issued patent, or one that's

filed and pending
with bad claims, if there's one that could be
modified to make it troublesome,

you have to find it. So AI is not, by any stretch,
fault intolerant yet.

It could miss things. So as a result, people
are not willing to invest the kind of money we're talking
about in a drug with anything

less than perfect. So the way they're done is
there are definitely databases.

Usually, all of them are used. And searches will be
run frequently for--

I actually helped
with the first freedom to operate for Cas9
for Dr. Doudna.

I think there were probably
hundreds or thousands of patents that were gone through for that. Believe it or not, there
was a weird little problem.

Actually, I'll tell a side-- I always tell
stories, I'm sorry. Maybe I'm not
supposed to do that. Is a story OK?

SPEAKER: A story is perfect. That's where you get the
context and really, the deeper understanding, I think.

VERN NORVIEL: And I'm
going to talk a little. I'll also work in the
idea of how to get this done for a rational cost.

So places like
Berkeley and, oddly, not Stanford, but Berkeley,
UCSF Law, and other schools,

law schools now, have classes
where students do freedom to operate studies
under the supervision

of a lawyer for free. And the first person, the
first benefactor of one

of these attempts at a
class many years ago was-- this young woman
walks in and she says

she has a way of editing genes. And I will be honest, in the
back of my mind I thought, yeah, right, what a chump!

I thought it might
be a great class project for these students. And sure enough,
they found a problem.

And when the movie is made,
the village idiot will be-- I hope nobody's on this--

well, I can't
control it, I guess. But I'm going to insult
Northwestern University here. I think they know
they had a problem.

But Northwestern had actually
filed on gene editing with the CAS enzymes long before
Jennifer and Emmanuelle came up

with it. And in fact, not
only had they filed, but the patent was right
on the brink of allowance.

All that had to be done
was a simple phone call with the examiner
to get it allowed, and it would have covered
all of gene editing,

not just Cas9 but Cas12
and CAS, et cetera. But the genius at Northwestern's
tech transfer office

decided it wasn't
worth anything, so they let it go abandoned
when they really only needed to invest a few hundred
dollars more to get it allowed.

Well, we found this
patent in this class. And I believe Jennifer even
flew back to meet the professor.

Because I said, look,
this is a problem. We got to make this go away. I didn't know-- I couldn't
tell on the computer

yet that it had been abandoned. So she goes back there
and they say, yeah, well, we abandoned it. And it's like, are
you kidding me?

So in any event-- and there are ways to
revive abandoned patents.

But unfortunately, they
had managed to seal off any of those methods. So yeah, the original
CRISPR patent

was actually abandoned by
Northwestern University. So it took us-- we had to
look at thousands of patents

to find that one, though. So the answer to your question
is they are a mile wide

and an inch deep kind of things. And you got to find
that one problem in all of those thousands of patents.

And as a result, there's
no tolerance for mistakes. And you have to look at
everything that's even close.

Now, what that has developed is
this kind of ecosystem, at least in the Bay Area.

And I think that some of
the universities in Boston are going to start it. The problem is that's even more
expensive than filing a patent.

That might be 50,000 or 100,000
bucks to do this freedom to operate searches. But there has been created, this
ecosystem of nice successful law

schools that are now doing these
things for the biotech community under the tutelage of
a practicing lawyer.

And I found that they're
very high quality. The VCs now accept them as real.

And it's a way to
get it done for free because this is a
super expensive part. And it's really hard to wedge
it in to an early budget

of a company.  SPEAKER: That's
really interesting.

Interesting to hear-- [INTERPOSING VOICES] VERN NORVIEL: I have to go talk
to Hank Greely at Stanford. And that's why the hell
Stanford is so behind her.

SPEAKER: Your freedom
to operate studies. Well, I assume it's
not part of this class,

so we'll assume that. But it's interesting to just
understand what goes into that

and how broad it is. And it's not
something that you're going to do maybe with
your two co-founders.

They're not going to
do that themselves. You need to be much more
methodical, supervised, professional about it.

VERN NORVIEL: And
the people that do it have to be technically
trained as well. So the students that are done
doing these at these law schools

almost all have PhDs or at
least bachelor's degrees in the relevant area. And the people that
do it at the law

firms all have PhDs
